subject: Art
title: Alignment
description: Creating order and connection by aligning elements along invisible lines.

hook.text: When a picture is hung slightly crooked, it drives you crazy. Your brain craves alignment. In design, aligning elements creates order, professionalism, and visual calm.

buildup.text: Alignment types: left-aligned (most common for text â€” creates a strong left edge), center-aligned (formal, symmetrical), right-aligned (less common, used for contrast), and justified (both edges aligned).

discovery.text: Every element should align with something else. When elements share an edge or center line, they feel connected and organized. Random placement without alignment creates chaos.

twist.text: Avoid centering everything â€” it's the amateur's default. Center alignment has no strong edge for the eye to follow. Left or right alignment creates a clean vertical edge that anchors the layout.

climax.text: Look at any professional poster: elements align to invisible vertical and horizontal lines. Now look at a poorly designed flyer: elements are scattered without alignment. The difference is immediately obvious.

punchline.text: Alignment is invisible glue. You don't see it, but you feel the difference when it's missing.

quiz.question: Why should you avoid centering all elements in a layout?
options: It creates no strong edge for the eye to follow and often looks amateur
Computers can't render center alignment well
